name: Leigh Disease
description: A rare disorder that affects the central nervous system. The disease most likely to occurs during an infant’s initial birth year, but may occur between the ages of two years and younger.
symptoms: General symptoms for infants include: diarrhea, vomiting, and dysphagia (trouble swallowing or sucking), leading to a failure to thrive. Early symptoms shows that the children are irritable and cry more often than normal and seizures possibility.
references: Leigh syndrome - Genetics Home Reference.U.S. National Library of Medicine. National Institutes of Health, n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: Mitochondrial Myopathy
description: Myopathy is a muscular disease where the muscle fibers aren’t able to function resulting in muscular weakness.
symptoms: Common muscle weakness, cramps, stiffness, spasm, and tetany
references: Mitochondrial Myopathies (MM). Muscular Dystrophy Association. N.p., 18 Jan. 2016. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: Friedreich's Ataxia - FRDA
description: Is a genetic, progressive, neurodegenerative movement disorders with a mean age of onset between 10 and 15 years. It is often associated cardiomyopathy, a disease of a cardiac muscle that leads to heart failure ,which could present as short upon exertion. Clinical findings and symptoms have found  that  FRDA is a result from degenerative changes in the sensory nerve fibers at the spine in structures known as dorsal root ganglia.
symptoms: Ataxia involves inadequate muscle coordination that leads to unsteady in an unsteady gain , and poor control of muscle coordination. Muscles in the throat and mouth may lead to slurred speech. Lateral or sideways curvature of the spine (scoliosis) or foot abnormalities may occur.
references: NORD National Organization for Rare Disorders . (n.d.). Friedreich’s Ataxia. Retrieved March 10 , 2017, from https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/friedreichs-ataxia/

name: MERRF - Myoclonus Epilepsy with Ragged-Red Fibers
description: An extremely rare disease that affects the muscles and the nervous system.
symptoms: Related symptoms involve: progressive myoclonic epilepsy, short stature, hearing loss, lactic acidosis, exercise intolerance, and poor night vision; in addition, the disease shows Ragged Red Fibers - clumps of diseased mitochondria accumulate in the subsarcolemmal region of the muscle fiber and appear as Ragged Red Fibers when muscle is stained with modified Gömöri trichrome stain
references: MERRF - Genetics Home Reference. U.S. National Library of Medicine. National Institutes of Health, n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: Kearns-Sayre Syndrome KSS
description: KSS is a set of syndromes that is a form of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (abbreviated CPEO). CPEO is a disorder that slowly over time paralyzes the extraocular muscles and the disorder, KSS is when the individual has little to no control over the movement of their eyelids and eye.
symptoms: KSS shows the difficulty of opening the eyelids, eye movements eventually become limited causing a person to rely more on turning the head side to side or up and down to view objects in the peripheral visual field.
references: Kearns-Sayre syndrome - Genetics Home Reference. U.S. National Library of Medicine. National Institutes of Health, n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: NARP
description: Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) causes signs and symptoms that will affect the nervous system
symptoms: General symptoms are numbness, tingling, or pain in the arms and legs, muscle weakness, and ataxia. Possible loss of vision, which has a possibility of causing a condition called retinitis pigmentosa, which will cause the light-sensing cells of a retina to gradually deteriorate.
references: Maternally Inherited Leigh Syndrome and NARP Syndrome.NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders). N.p., n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: MNGIE
description: Mitochondrial neurogastrointestinal encephalopathy (MNGIE) can affect several parts of the body, but usually the digestive system and the nervous system. This disease can appear from an infant to an adult and can worsen in time.
symptoms: Certain things that can happen in your digestive system is gastrointestinal dysmotility (Muscles and nerves of the digestive system do not move food through the digestive tracks well). This causes you to feel full despite eating little, trouble swallowing, nausea and vomiting. Certain things that can happen in your nervous system is tingling, numbness, and weakness in their limbs usually in the hands and feet, droopy eyelids, and hearing loss
references: Hirano, Michio. Mitochondrial Neurogastrointestinal Encephalopathy Disease. GeneReviews® [Internet]. U.S. National Library of Medicine, 14 Jan. 2016. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: Alpers Disease
description: Alpers disease starts off with seizures around the ages of 3 months to 5 years old. Then the child can’t have normal muscle tone or hypotonia, but the limbs appear stiff. There will also be grey matter in your brain. This doesn’t happen all the time, but it usually does happen. Then they lose intellectual functions like thinking and remembering, and might lost control of their arms and legs. Then their liver will fail completely.
symptoms: Alpers disease starts off with seizures around the ages of 3 months to 5 years old. Then the child can’t have normal muscle tone or hypotonia, but the limbs appear stiff. There will also be grey matter in your brain. This doesn’t happen all the time, but it usually does happen. Then they lose intellectual functions like thinking and remembering, and might lost control of their arms and legs. Then their liver will fail completely.
references: Alpers Disease. NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders). N.p., n.d. Web. 13 Mar. 2017.

name: Luft Disease
description: Also known as Hyper metabolic mitochondrial syndrome, is characterized as severe hypermetabolism and heat intolerance. Hyper-metabolism is the inusual increased rate of metabolic activity in the human body
symptoms: Patients diagnosed with with Luft’s disease may experience a wide array of symptoms. Some of the most common ones are: Muscle weakness, excessive perspiration, hyper-metabolism, lack of loss, and more.
references: Bullard , Z. (2016, November 7). Luft Disease - What is it? Retrieved March 10, 2017, from http://zachbullard.blogspot.ca/2016/11/luft-disease-what-is-it.html
